title: Will broadband companies start putting a data cap on our internet? - Quora

response.answer_text: So... I've been building and helping to build Internet service providers since the early 1980s (I'm going to count CSNET, along with SesquiNet, SCCSI, InfoHighway, Genuity, Enron Broadband, and the various CVC portfolio companies and others where I was more of an advisor). They all had one thing in common: bandwidth costs money. These days, that can be modified to "bandwidth costs real money, and lots of it". Sure, you get more bits per dollar spent, but it's gotten more expensive for each incremental step. Lots more expensive. So, yeah, there HAS to be some sort of limit on how much bandwidth you can consume, OR there has to be some sort of metered usage put in place. Otherwise, being a carrier is not a sustainable business model. The problem with the wireless business model - something called "broken bucket" (or "wasted coupon" in some cases) is that it's unfair. Works like this. The plan says "unlimited" but there's a little disclaimer that says something like "after X GB, your speeds will be throttled to the point that you either buy more or give up and don't use it" (more or less). Why? You get sold bandwidth in buckets - say $20 for 2GB. It's built into your baseline service, that "unlimited" thing. For some people, they blow through that, and get to buy more bandwidth at say $10 per 1GB. Or they get throttled. For others, they never touch the limit - maybe a few MB of download. So the carrier makes serious bank off every user that doesn't fill their bucket (hence the "broken bucket" name), but still also makes money off every user that goes into "extra bandwidth, please" territory. That's much, much harder in wire-line business, like cable companies. Because bandwidth is sold in maximum instantaneous speeds, not in aggregate capacity, but the back-end costs for Internet transit are all priced in total GB sent, not the speed at which it happened. And from the money they make net on what they charge you for the bandwidth versus what they pay for Internet transit? They have to pay to operate the rest of the business. And that takes boatloads of money. Here's some additional reading on the subject. Do follow the links in the other articles, which will take you to source material. Stan Hanks' answer to What are the most capital-intensive industries? Stan Hanks' answer to What do tech firms, including those not in the Tech 50, think about the issue of net neutrality, especially those whose community or customer base demands fast Internet service?

Unlimited tariffs are expensive and difficult to maintain for broadband providers, they need to use caps to maintain their network sanity. Most ISPs already have a cap, they just call it "acceptable use policy" and for mature ISPs in countries with good internet connectivity the AUP is normally high enough that just the top 5% of users reach it.

They already do in much of the industrialized world, but depending on your location, usage, how much competition is there, and some other factors that cap might or might not be problematic.  There are entire web sites devoted to discouraging operators from capping.Page on stopthecap.com Obviously this isn't popular with consumers, but given the rate of data consumption increases, how capital expensive broadband networks are to build, and how cord cutters are reducing the revenue for video providers I see many more operators implementing caps or making them lower.
